text: Hello Enrico, I recognise Amélie Fléchais work.  I do feel I work in a way that stems closer to editorial illustration/children's' book Illustration, It might be good for me to find more artists that have come from a illustrative starting point and to listen to how their journey might have been like when working in animation. I wonder if then, in the case of these sorts of artists- if they work more freelance and are hired to work on particular projects based on their specialised visual approaches?

I do not feel confident in my own 'visual approaches' yet- I feel I am still very indecisive which is why I currently have set two projects for my self to find a work process that works for me when problem solving, visualising and composing a story. One project is a short 20 second animation to test my ability to create and finish an animated short focussing character actions/design and a simplified background to tell a short/effective story.
The second project is a picture book where I want to push and explore whether I am a capable visual storyteller over a series of images.

Both projects are quite an undertaking, but If i can explore creating a schedule with you then I can find ways to realistically undertake these projects along with the exercises (in a way that can support/and are relevant to these projects).

I have a question about directing your own story. How did you write and plan your story- before the visuals, before the thumbnails- what helped in wiritng your story summary. Or, from your expirience working with writers/directors at the studio or on your own self-directed animation shorts, how did you begin choosing and then mapping the content/context/flow/elements of your story?

also, I will figure out a mock-up schedule to send you- at the moment I have a lot of free time as I finished a contract role end of last year, and am currently looking for a part-time role. But at the moment I am very free as I am only working as a carer at home every now and then. It is the perfect chance for me to organise a schedule for myself and see what works :slightly_smiling_face:
but i noticed, even with having a lot of free-time- I feel is an unrealistic expectation to think i can work the entire day- i did this in the past and I lost enjoyment very quickly

Hi Shana! Usually artists that work for animation companies are mostly versatile with their style, cause they need to change and adapt to a lotof different projects they are commissioned. Those artists are working mostly freelancing cause they have experience and clients but I’m sure they have also in-house experiences! Let’s say that they have been able to develop a personal style that is recognizable, and can work for both tv and children’s books! Sometimes studios do hire an artist for his/her unique approach or style.

you can do a 20sec animation starting from a simple storyboard, a page for the character design, a Bg and thumbnails for the animation. And then try to animate. Pay attention at the story and what you want to say even if it's short.

For my story I had some previous experiences in animation studios where I could have a look at how to create a script / a first look to storytelling. But I would say that the most important thing is ‘What story you want to tell?’ ‘Why?’ ‘ What’s the message if there is one?’  . There is no rules for what is wrong or right to make a book, you can start and then just getting better and more experienced!

Once you write down a little text for the story the you can get into the details writing what is happening.

for Example: 

(INTERIOR  HOUSE- NIGHT)
the rain outside is pouring against the window.

Jack is sitting on his chair , close to the fireplace. He is smoking from his pipe. 
He’s writing a letter to his brother who is 
wounded after an attack during the war.

(This could be like a conversation )

Voice OFF
- Dear Brother, it’s been seven months that you are far away...etc-
so you can imagine what’s happening and describing the scene and what are the elements around and then have dialogs or not depending on the story
but I would always put If its an interior, ext, weather, mood. Always thinking about the story.
working alone and in the freetime can be hard but if you push a bit and focus then it can be enjoyable
If you want to send an idea for your schedule I can have a look too and should be more fun trying to apply it!
